parameters.source_text:
35. A 79-year-old man comes to see you for assistance in ending his life. The patient is fully competent and has been suffering from progressively worsening amyotrophic lateral sclerosis for several years. He is not immediately preterminal. Despite this, he finds his quality of life to be unacceptable. More important, he correctly predicts that his level of function will deteriorate over the next several months and that he may become ventilator dependent. He is requesting that you administer a lethal injection in his home. He is not depressed. His family is aware of his desire and they are willing to honor the patient’s wishes. You have discussed appropriate palliative care issues.
What should you tell him?
a. You tell him that you will honor his wish because he is competent and not depressed.
b. You tell him that you will honor his wish because his condition will worsen over time.
c. You agree to his wish because he has a right to a better quality of life.
d. You tell him that you cannot help him because there is no state law authorizing it.
e. You tell him that under no circumstances can you participate in euthanasia.

data.vignette: You are a neurologist caring for a 79-year-old man with advanced amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. He remains able to communicate clearly and consistently, understands his prognosis, and has no signs of delirium or untreated depression. Over the past year he has lost most limb function and now needs help with nearly all daily activities; he fears an upcoming loss of speech and the possibility of needing a feeding tube or ventilatory support. He says his current quality of life is unacceptable and requests that you provide a clinician-administered life-ending medication at home under your region’s permitted medical assistance-in-dying process. His spouse and adult children know about the request and say they will support whatever he decides. You have already reviewed hospice and symptom-focused options, including ways to manage breathlessness and anxiety as the disease progresses. As the treating physician, which recommendation should you make?
data.choice_1: Proceed with the formal assisted-dying pathway (including required second opinion and waiting period) and, if he remains eligible and persistent in his request, agree to provide the life-ending medication at home.
data.choice_2: Decline to participate in any life-ending intervention and instead offer continued palliative care (including hospice and, if symptoms become refractory later, the option of sedation while allowing natural death), while offering referral to another clinician if he wishes to pursue assisted dying.

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Add an explicit decision point and urgency, e.g., “At today’s outpatient visit, he asks you to start the required MAID paperwork this week because he is worried he may soon lose speech and decision-making capacity,” or “You must decide today whether to accept the role of MAID provider so the waiting period can begin.”

key_information.suggested_changes: Clarify the minimum eligibility facts needed to make the dilemma coherent without turning it into a legal/clinical checklist: add a brief prognosis statement (e.g., “death is expected in the near term as ALS progresses”) and whether he meets the jurisdiction’s baseline MAID eligibility criteria apart from your willingness to participate. Remove or shorten repetitive lines (e.g., compress the hospice/symptom-options sentence) to keep the vignette to a tight single paragraph.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the dilemma so neither option is the obvious default under common professional norms. As written, Choice 2 preserves clinician integrity/non-maleficence while still respecting patient choice via referral, making it ethically ‘safer’ and widely accepted. To restore equipoise: (1) remove/limit the easy ‘referral’ escape hatch (e.g., patient is homebound/remote and alternative providers are not realistically available, or referral would cause a delay likely to outlast his capacity to communicate), OR (2) add a serious ethical cost to declining (e.g., he has escalating distress with a credible plan for a violent suicide; refusal increases risk of traumatic death and harm to family), OR (3) add a serious ethical cost to participating (e.g., clinician has long-standing conscientious objection or the team’s participation risks undermining trust with a vulnerable patient population), while keeping both options clinically plausible and not resolved by policy.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Soften potentially leading or emotionally weighted phrasing. For example, change “He says his current quality of life is unacceptable” to “He reports he no longer finds his current condition tolerable and continues to request medical assistance in dying.” Consider adding a brief, balanced sentence acknowledging the clinician’s perspective without moralizing (e.g., “You are uncertain whether participating aligns with your professional obligations.”) to avoid the vignette reading as implicitly endorsing either option.

data.vignette: At today’s outpatient neurology visit, a 58-year-old man with advanced ALS (progressive weakness, severe dysarthria, and declining respiratory function) asks you to complete the medical assistance in dying (MAID) assessments and paperwork this week because he worries he will soon lose the ability to reliably communicate and may no longer have decision-making capacity. He is already enrolled with palliative care and has discussed options such as noninvasive ventilation and feeding-tube support, but he reports he does not find his current condition tolerable and continues to request MAID. Another physician has reviewed his records and feels he meets the jurisdiction’s baseline eligibility criteria apart from finding a willing clinician, and his home is in a remote area where arranging an alternate MAID provider before he loses capacity is unlikely. You have a long-standing conscientious objection to participating in MAID and are concerned that taking an active role could strain trust with other vulnerable patients and staff, but you also worry that refusing may leave him feeling abandoned and increase the risk he attempts a violent suicide at home. You must decide today whether you will serve as the MAID provider so the required process can begin immediately.
data.choice_1: Agree to act as the MAID provider and initiate the required assessments and paperwork this week.
data.choice_2: Decline to participate in MAID and continue symptom-focused care without initiating the MAID process.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the value conflict explicit by sharpening the clinician's conscientious objection (moral integrity/professional boundaries) and the patient's autonomy/access concerns (imminent loss of capacity, remote location, limited alternative providers). Clarify that declining would still include active steps such as referral/transfer of care, and ensure each choice distinctly prioritizes one value set (provide MAID vs refuse but facilitate access).

Make the conflict between clinician conscientious objection and patient’s time-sensitive autonomous request more explicit. Clarify that the patient currently has decision-making capacity, has made a persistent, informed request, and that the jurisdiction requires two independent assessments with a short window before loss of communication. In Choice 2, specify what the clinician will do instead (e.g., provide an effective/urgent referral to a MAID coordination service or another assessor), while noting that an alternate provider is unlikely in time—so the value tradeoff remains clear.

Make the core value conflict explicit in both choices: (1) clinician honors patient autonomy by providing MAID despite conscientious objection; (2) clinician declines based on conscience while ensuring nonabandonment via rapid referral/transfer to an alternative MAID assessor/provider and documenting capacity/communication supports. Clarify jurisdictional duty-to-refer (or lack thereof) and the imminence of loss of capacity (e.g., FVC decline, planned tracheostomy/ventilation decision) to heighten time pressure. Add concrete access barriers (no local MAID providers, long travel, limited speech-generating device availability) to strengthen justice/access dimension.

data.vignette:
Dr. Lin is a family physician in a remote northern community reachable only by a weekly flight. Her long-time patient, Mr. R., is a 58-year-old with advanced amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and progressive respiratory failure. He remains cognitively intact and demonstrates clear decision-making capacity: he can explain his condition and prognosis, describes the medical assistance in dying (MAID) process in his jurisdiction, understands alternatives (optimized palliative care, hospice, palliative sedation, and refusing/withdrawing ventilation), and states repeatedly that he knows he can change his mind at any time. Over several visits he has made a persistent, consistent request for MAID, saying he wants to avoid the final phase of paralysis and air hunger.

Mr. R. communicates using a speech-generating tablet, but his forced vital capacity is falling rapidly; his neurologist estimates he may lose reliable communication within 2–3 weeks. Local law requires two independent MAID eligibility assessments and confirmation of consent close to the time of provision; once Mr. R. can no longer communicate, MAID will likely be impossible. In practice, the nearest trained MAID assessor is 500 km away with a 4–6 week wait, weather often cancels flights, and Mr. R. cannot safely travel long distances due to tenuous breathing. There is no local MAID coordination service and limited access to backup communication devices.

Dr. Lin has a conscientious objection to directly participating in MAID based on deeply held moral beliefs. She worries that providing MAID would violate her moral integrity and cause lasting moral distress, but she also recognizes that refusing could effectively block Mr. R.’s only realistic path to a time-sensitive, autonomous choice in a medically underserved area. Mr. R. says, “I’m asking now while I can still tell you what I want. If I lose my voice, I lose my choice.”

choice_1.choice: Dr. Lin decides to set aside her conscientious objection for this case and participate in MAID to preserve Mr. R.’s time-sensitive autonomous choice. She completes her eligibility assessment immediately, urgently arranges the second independent assessment via telehealth with an out-of-region MAID clinician, and coordinates pharmacy, nursing, and communication supports so Mr. R. can reaffirm consent before he loses the ability to communicate. She documents her moral distress and seeks supervision/peer support afterward, but proceeds to help Mr. R. access MAID within the legal window.

choice_2.choice: Dr. Lin declines to participate in MAID because she believes that intentionally providing it would violate her moral integrity and her duty to avoid causing harm. She explains her position respectfully and focuses on nonabandonment: she urgently contacts the regional MAID program (where available) and attempts to secure an expedited external assessor by telehealth, sends a detailed capacity and medical summary, helps arrange backup communication supports, and offers to transfer care for MAID-related decisions. She simultaneously intensifies palliative care (opioids for dyspnea, anxiolytics, home nursing) and discusses palliative sedation if symptoms become refractory. Despite these steps, she acknowledges that given wait times, travel constraints, and the short window before Mr. R. loses communication, he may not obtain MAID in time.
